claim_reports.claim_text: Research helps inform farmers on optimal practices to maximize crop yields and minimize atmospheric losses.
claim_reports.verdict_summary: The evidence supports the claim that research informs farmers on optimal practices to maximize crop yields and minimize atmospheric losses, with multiple high-reliability sources indicating adaptive measures and regenerative practices can mitigate yield losses. However, there are also unclear signals regarding the impact of climate change and CO2 levels on crop yields, suggesting a complex relationship that requires further investigation.

supports.title: Climate change cuts global crop yields, even when farmers adapt
supports.evidence_summary: The research indicates that while climate change will negatively impact crop yields, farmers can implement adaptive measures that help mitigate some of these losses, thus informing them on optimal practices to maximize yields.
supports.snippet: A sweeping new analysis finds that rising global temperatures will dampen the world's capacity to produce food from most staple crops.

supports.title: Sustainable food systems transformation in the face of climate change
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that regenerative agricultural practices can improve soil health and increase crop yields, supporting the claim that research informs farmers on optimal practices for maximizing yields and minimizing atmospheric losses.
supports.snippet: For example, long-term research trials have demonstrated that regenerative farming methods can improve soil health, increase crop yields, and ...

supports.title: Enhancing resilience in specialty crop production in a changing ...
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence discusses how research informs farmers about adaptive measures that can mitigate yield losses due to climate change, thus supporting the claim that research helps optimize practices for crop yields.
supports.snippet: This paper highlights the importance of building resilience through innovative farming techniques, sustainable practices, and robust research.

claim_reports.claim_text: Human-produced gases can have bad effects on the planet, including changing the climate and weather.
claim_reports.verdict_summary: Multiple high-reliability sources confirm that human-produced greenhouse gases adversely affect the climate, leading to changes in weather patterns and extreme weather events. This includes evidence from NASA, the U.S. Energy Information Administration, and Climate Central, all of which align with the claim.

supports.title: Climate change: atmospheric carbon dioxide
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that human-caused emissions of greenhouse gases adversely affect the climate, supporting the claim that these gases can change the climate and weather.
supports.snippet: By adding more carbon dioxide to the atmosphere, people are amplifying the natural greenhouse effect, causing global temperature to rise. According to ...

supports.title: Greenhouse gases' effect on climate - U.S. Energy Information ... - EIA
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence discusses how human-produced greenhouse gases (GHGs) contribute to climate change, leading to extreme weather events and altering precipitation patterns, which aligns with the claim about the negative effects of these gases on the planet.
supports.snippet: Greenhouse gases warm the planet​​ Rising temperatures may produce changes in precipitation patterns, storm severity, and sea level. Collectively ...

supports.title: The Causes of Climate Change - NASA Science
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that human-caused emissions of greenhouse gases adversely affect the climate, supporting the claim that these gases can change the climate and weather.
supports.snippet: The greenhouse effect is essential to life on Earth, but human-made emissions in the atmosphere are trapping and slowing heat loss to space.

supports.title: What Is the Greenhouse Effect? - NASA Science
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence discusses how human-produced greenhouse gases (GHGs) contribute to climate change and extreme weather events, confirming the claim that human-produced gases can negatively affect the planet's climate and weather patterns.
supports.snippet: Greenhouse gases in Earth's atmosphere trap some of the heat from the sun. It prevents the heat from escaping back into space at night. This ...

supports.title: Heat-Trapping Pollution - Climate Central
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence discusses how greenhouse gases, including carbon dioxide, contribute to climate change and warming, confirming that human-produced gases can negatively affect the planet's climate and weather.
supports.snippet: Carbon dioxide accounts for about 75% of global human-caused greenhouse gas emissions and has contributed the most to cumulative warming.

claim_reports.claim_text: Greenhouse gases trap heat and energy from the Sun.
claim_reports.verdict_summary: The evidence from multiple high-reliability sources consistently confirms that greenhouse gases absorb and re-radiate heat, effectively trapping energy from the Sun and preventing its loss to space. This supports the claim that greenhouse gases trap heat and energy.

supports.title: Greenhouse effect - Understanding Global Change
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence explains that greenhouse gases absorb and re-radiate heat, effectively trapping energy from the Sun and preventing its loss to space, which confirms the claim about greenhouse gases trapping heat.
supports.snippet: Altogether, this cycle of absorption and re-radiation by greenhouse gases impedes the loss of heat from our atmosphere to space, creating the greenhouse effect.

supports.title: [PDF] The Greenhouse Gases
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence explains that greenhouse gases absorb heat from the Earth's surface and trap it in the atmosphere, which aligns with the claim that greenhouse gases trap heat and energy from the Sun.
supports.snippet: The Sun's energy is radiated in all directions in the form of photons, or packets of solar energy. ... How do the greenhouse gases trap heat? First they absorb ...

supports.title: Climate and Earth's Energy Budget - Earth Observatory - NASA
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence explains that greenhouse gases absorb thermal infrared energy, which leads to an increase in temperature and effectively traps heat within the Earth's atmosphere, confirming the claim about greenhouse gases trapping heat and energy from the Sun.
supports.snippet: When greenhouse gas molecules absorb thermal infrared energy, their temperature rises. Like coals from a fire that are warm but not glowing, ...

supports.title: FAQs • What are the “Greenhouse Effect” and “Greenhouse Gase
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that greenhouse gases absorb heat radiating from Earth's surface, preventing it from escaping into space, which is a key aspect of the greenhouse effect. This mechanism is described as trapping heat, similar to how a comforter retains body heat.
supports.snippet: Thus, greenhouse gases trap heat within the surface-troposphere system. This is called the greenhouse effect. (Definition courtesy of IPCC AR4.) Climate ...

supports.title: What Are Greenhouse Gases and Why Do They Matter - Climate
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that greenhouse gases absorb heat radiating from Earth's surface, effectively trapping heat in the atmosphere, which aligns with the claim that greenhouse gases trap heat and energy from the Sun.
supports.snippet: Greenhouse gases (GHGs) are a category of gases that absorb heat energy emitted from the planet's surface and they remain in Earth's atmosphere for a long time.

supports.title: What is the greenhouse effect? - NASA Science
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that greenhouse gases absorb heat radiating from Earth's surface, effectively trapping heat and energy from the Sun, which contributes to the greenhouse effect and global warming.
supports.snippet: The greenhouse effect is the process through which heat is trapped near Earth's surface by substances known as 'greenhouse gases.'

claim_reports.claim_text: Air samples collected in flight help identify emission sources not measurable on the ground.
claim_reports.verdict_summary: Multiple high-reliability sources indicate that airborne measurements, particularly using the AirCore system, effectively quantify urban emissions of greenhouse gases and can identify emission sources not measurable from the ground. This is supported by a Purdue project highlighting underestimations of N2O emissions and corroborated by additional studies on aircraft-based sampling.

supports.title: Aviation senior project for sampling atmospheric emissions takes flight
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that airborne measurements using the AirCore system effectively quantify urban emissions of greenhouse gases, demonstrating that air samples collected in flight can reveal significant emissions not measurable on the ground, particularly highlighting underestimations of N2O emissions in urban areas.
supports.snippet: Aviation requires a lighter weight, simplified air sampling device that can be installed with minimal effort in existing aircraft as well as the ...

supports.snippet: In conclusion, our study demonstrates that aircraft-based AirCore sampling can be useful to estimate urban N2O and CH4 emissions combined with ...

supports.snippet: By flying at low altitudes, aircraft-based monitoring targets emissions sources at a lower spatial resolution. This makes them effective for ...

claim_reports.claim_text: Fertilizers used in farming can release nutrients into the atmosphere.
claim_reports.verdict_summary: The evidence presents a mixed stance on the claim that fertilizers release nutrients into the atmosphere. While several high-reliability sources indicate that fertilizers, particularly those with synthetic nitrogen, can lead to the release of nitrous oxide and ammonia into the atmosphere, a medium-reliability source refutes the claim by emphasizing the role of fertilizers in promoting plant health without mentioning atmospheric nutrient release. The NOAA source adds to the ambiguity by discussing benefits without confirming nutrient release.

refutes.title: Using Advanced Fertilizers is Helping to Fight Climate Change
refutes.evidence_summary: The article discusses the role of fertilizers in promoting healthy plants, which absorb CO2 from the atmosphere, but it does not provide evidence that fertilizers themselves release nutrients into the atmosphere.
refutes.snippet: By keeping plants healthy, fertilizers are responsible for strong roots, which prevents soil erosion and in turn protects green spaces and promotes biodiverse ...

supports.title: Four reasons why the world needs to limit nitrogen pollution - UNEP
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that fertilizers, particularly those containing synthetic nitrogen, can lead to the release of nitrous oxide into the atmosphere through microbial reactions in the soil, supporting the claim that fertilizers can release nutrients into the atmosphere.
supports.snippet: When nitrogen in its active form, such as in fertiliser, is exposed to soil, microbial reactions take place that release nitrous oxide. This gas ...

supports.title: The impact of organic fertilizer replacement on greenhouse gas ...
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence discusses how excess nitrogen from fertilizers can escape into the atmosphere, contributing to air pollution and greenhouse gas emissions, which supports the claim that fertilizers can release nutrients into the atmosphere.
supports.snippet: The results indicated that organic fertilizers replacing chemical fertilizers significantly decreased N 2 O emissions, but increasing global warming potential ...

supports.title: The What, Where, and Why of Fertilizer - RMI
supports.evidence_summary: The article discusses the loss of ammonia gas into the atmosphere as a result of fertilizer use, indicating that fertilizers can indeed release nutrients into the air.
supports.snippet: This process involves the loss of the ammonia gas into the atmosphere. The extent of the loss depends on weather conditions, the type of ...

supports.title: Understanding the Impacts of Synthetic Nitrogen on Air and Water ...
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence discusses how excess nitrogen from fertilizers can escape into the atmosphere, contributing to air pollution and the formation of ground-level ozone and fine particulate matter (PM2.5).
supports.snippet: Excess nitrogen has also contributed to acid rain, polluted drinking water, and caused oxygen depletion and “dead zones” in water bodies, which ...

mixed.title: What causes nutrient pollution? - NOAA's National Ocean Service
mixed.evidence_summary: The article discusses the use of fertilizers in agriculture and their role in promoting healthy plants, which absorb CO2 from the atmosphere. However, it does not explicitly state that fertilizers release nutrients into the atmosphere, focusing instead on their benefits and potential environmental impacts.
mixed.snippet: Nutrient pollution from humans can make HABs much worse. Nitrogen and phosphorus are commonly used in agriculture, lawns, and other human activities.

claim_reports.claim_text: Instruments collect air samples to measure different gases in the atmosphere.
claim_reports.verdict_summary: The evidence strongly supports the claim that instruments collect air samples to measure different gases in the atmosphere, with multiple high-reliability sources detailing various air sampling methods and technologies used for this purpose.

supports.title: AirCore Atmospheric Sampling System - Global Monitoring Laboratory
supports.evidence_summary: The article discusses various instruments used for air monitoring, including automatic air samplers that collect air samples to analyze particulate matter and gases in the atmosphere, thus supporting the claim.
supports.snippet: The AirCore is an innovative atmospheric sampling system that consists of a long tubing, usually in the shape of a coil, that can sample the surrounding ...

supports.title: Measuring & Analyzing Greenhouse Gases: Behind the Scenes
supports.evidence_summary: The article discusses ambient air sampling, which involves collecting and analyzing air samples to measure various pollutants and gases in the atmosphere, thus supporting the claim.
supports.snippet: The instrument used is called a Non-Dispersive Infrared analyzer (NDIR). The air we want to measure is sent into a small chamber, and an infrared light at a ...

supports.title: Whole Air Sampling | NASA Airborne Science Program
supports.evidence_summary: The article discusses ambient air sampling, which involves collecting air samples to analyze various gases and pollutants in the atmosphere, supporting the claim that instruments are used for this purpose.
supports.snippet: The Whole Air Sampler (WAS) collects samples from airborne platforms for detailed analysis of a wide range of trace gases.

supports.title: Air quality gas analyzers - Acoem
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that instruments, specifically gas analyzers and particulate samplers, are used to collect air samples for measuring various gases and pollutants in the atmosphere.
supports.snippet: Discover our range of air quality gas analysers. We develop, manufacture and maintain instruments to monitor gas pollutants present in ambient & indoor air.

supports.title: Air Sampling & Why We Need It | Zefon International
supports.evidence_summary: The article discusses ambient air sampling as a process that collects and analyzes gases and particles from the atmosphere to assess pollution levels, confirming that instruments are used to measure different gases in the air.
supports.snippet: Air sampling is a process used to determine what airborne contaminants are present in an environment. It uses special instruments to detect contaminants.

supports.title: Apex Instruments: Leading Manufacturer of Air Monitoring Equipment
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence describes how air monitoring instruments, such as gas analyzers and particulate samplers, are used to collect air samples and measure various gases and particulate matter in the atmosphere, supporting the claim.
supports.snippet: WORLD LEADER IN AIR MONITORING EQUIPMENT ... Apex Instruments designs, manufactures and distributes durable emission and ambient measurement sampling equipment.

claim_reports.claim_text: Research also investigates emissions from cars, landfills, and power plants in cities.
claim_reports.verdict_summary: The evidence strongly supports the claim, with two high-reliability sources discussing emissions from cars, landfills, and industrial facilities in cities. The AQMD report and the comprehensive analysis of air pollution in industrial clusters both confirm the investigation of these emissions.

supports.title: 50 Years of Progress - AQMD
supports.evidence_summary: The article discusses various sources of air pollution, including emissions from cars, landfills, and industrial facilities, which aligns with the claim about research investigating emissions from these sources in cities.
supports.snippet: ... landfills emitting toxic gases, power plants emitting nitrogen oxides, even rendering plants that processed animal wastes. Air quality regulations ...

supports.title: Air pollution in industrial clusters: A comprehensive analysis and ...
supports.evidence_summary: The article discusses the historical context of air pollution in Los Angeles, mentioning various sources of emissions, including industrial activities, vehicles, and waste management practices, which aligns with the claim about emissions from cars, landfills, and power plants in cities.
supports.snippet: This study focuses on the Tehran province, Iran, aiming to clarify the role of different industrial activities in emitting air pollution.

unclear.snippet: Landfills generate methane as organic waste decomposes. Here's how we can mitigate and prevent these climate-warming emissions.

transcript_data.text: [Music] [Music] we can think of the atmosphere as a mix of all sorts of gases that surrounds our planet some gases that humans produce can have bad effects on the planet including changing the climate and weather many of the human produced gases are called greenhouse gases these are gases that trap heat and energy from the Sun hi my name is Eric I'm an atmospheric scientist I study climate and greenhouse gases my group's research we really try to understand what's impact in the atmosphere and how that impacts climate Eric and his team study the atmosphere and measure the levels of gases that make it up including greenhouse gases the goals are to better understand where harmful gases are coming from but first they have to collect gases in the atmosphere and to do this they collect samples of air using special tools our instruments are designed to measure the contents of the atmosphere much like weather station would measure wind or rainfall or snowfall our instruments are designed to measure the molecules the components of the air that were actually in these instruments are able to take snapshots of the amount of different gases in the atmosphere at a given time which helps scientists investigate sources of greenhouse gases but since Eric and his team are thinking about the atmosphere they have an interesting approach to collecting their samples we have instrumentation that will put in different places sometimes we'll put it on an airplane and we'll actually fly the airplane around to different regions that were interested in studying the sources will collect air into inlets on the side of the airplane and actually measure it on instruments in the airplane by collecting samples in flight they are able to identify different emission sources that may not be measurable on the ground pretty cool but how does collecting air above the ground tell us about what is happening on the ground we can think about it this bees fly around from flower to flower as they fly pollen gets attached to them if we looked at a bee after a day of flying around we would be able to tell where it had been by looking at the types of pollen it collected Eric and his team are kind of like bees they fly around collecting samples of air and the samples are able to tell us about what is in the air they spend a lot of time flying and collecting samples over farms for this project we very much want to understand the impacts of how we grow our crops on the atmosphere so in order to grow crops you need to plant seeds you might put quite a lot of fertilizer down a lot of the nutrients from fertilizer going to the growing of the crops but not all of the nutrients make their way into the crops and the number of them are lost to the atmosphere by focusing on flying over farms they are able to tell if the fertilizers that farmers are using are good or bad for the atmosphere as we get towards answers we can help inform farmers on what our optimal practices to have them both get their best crop yields but minimize the losses to the atmosphere but their research doesn't just stop at farms they also fly over cities and other areas or fly downwind of cities to try to understand how much is being emitted from all the cars and vehicles in the city how much is coming out of landfills and power plants this research is important because in order to understand how the atmosphere is changing we have to understand what is making it change this research helps us determine where the problem is so we can fix it but don't let just the scientist do it all themselves you can help reduce your impact on the earth too so if one is concerned about what impacts you have on the atmosphere there are different actions that can be taken the most important thing is to simply be cognizant and aware of what you're doing being aware of subtle things even light bulbs on leaving the TV on when you're not watching it all of those small things do add up but there's also simply power being aware of the problem and then collective action that can come out of that do you want to be a scientist like Eric and his team try making your own sampling device [Music]
